news.title: Exploring Christmas behind bars
news.content:
Story by Abigirl Tembo
Christmas Day is a time for joy, love and celebration for many, but for those behind bars, it’s a stark reminder of their isolation.
As the ZBC News walked through the prison yards, some inmates were eagerly unwrapping gifts and enjoying treats brought by their loved ones.
However, others sat alone, their faces a picture of sadness and longing.
“I’m grateful that my family remembered me. It’s a small comfort, but it means a lot to me,” said an inmate.
But not all inmates were as fortunate. Many had not received any visitors or gifts, and the loneliness was evident.
“It’s hard to be away from my family on Christmas Day. I have been here for six years and I have never received a single visitor. I just wish someone would come and visit me, just to remind me that I’m not forgotten,” and inmate narrated.
“My family please forgive me. I am serving my time and I am sorry, please come and visit me.”
“I wish someone could come and visit me. Even for 30 minutes only,” said another inmate.

news.title: Christmas gifts: Families welcome newborns on joyous holiday
news.content:
Story by Grace Sibanda
While others were celebrating Christmas with friends and family, delighted mothers rejoiced after receiving their newborns, with some terming them “Christmas miracles.”
Christmas Day is a time of joy, love and celebration, for some families, this Christmas was a time to welcome new additions to their families.
“I am leaving this Christmas with my baby girl and this is a happy day for me. I will always remember this day as a day I brought my baby to the earth with no hustle at all. I am leaving with no stitch or any pain at all,” said a mother.
The maternity ward this Christmas was a hive of activity as new mothers suckled their newly-born babies while others hummed their new borns to sleep.
The new mothers cited how Christmas Day will always hold fond memories as it is a day their Christmas miracles were brought into the world, symbolically the day that Jesus Christ was born.
“I am so happy for my little Christmas gift, she is so amazing and I wouldn’t have asked for a better gift,” a mother said.
Another added, “Christmas will always be a special day for me and my family as this is the day I got my first child, I am more than happy.”

news.title: Meet and Greet initiative excites tourists
news.content:
Story by Mhlomuli Ncube
Government says the Meet and Greet Concept where tourists are welcomed personally by the Ministry of Tourism and Hospitality Industry is a culmination of a transformative growth plan for the sector.
The Tourism Meet and Greet initiative has also excited tourists who expressed joy at the country’s hospitality approach.
Many visiting Zimbabwe’s tourism capital Victoria Falls testify of a great welcoming moment which is unique and places the country at the pinnacle of destinations to visit.
“I am travelling from California, USA and am visiting Zimbabwe to see the Victoria Falls. Thank you for the amazing gift, we love it,” a tourist told the ZBC News.

news.title: Zimbabweans honoured in China
news.content:
Story by Jonathan Marerwa in Beijing, China
Two Zimbabweans based in China have been honoured by the Public Diplomacy Network for promoting Africa-China co-operation.
The two, Bridget Mutambirwa and Melody Zekey Pand, were presented with the Public Diplomacy Persons of the Year award during a ceremony held recently in Beijing, becoming the first Africans and women to get such recognition.
Mutambirwa and Pand are media personalities and have both been mouthpieces of the Africa-China co-operation initiative.

news.title: ZRP’s festive season campaigns intensified
news.content:
Tafara Chikumira
The Zimbabwe Republic Police in the Midlands province has intensified campaigns on traffic and crime awareness during the festive period, imploring the public to be on high alert for possible mishaps associated with the season.
With massive deployments having been made across districts, the provincial police team is currently holding campaigns to conscientise the public on the new trends being used by robbers and thieves, while urging motorists to adhere to road rules during the holidays.
